questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling of her hands and wrists. She has been unable to continue her daily activities like writing or driving. She has had a nonpruritic generalized rash for 4 days. She had a fever and a runny nose one week ago which resolved with over-the-counter medication. She is sexually active with a male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. She works as an attendant at an amusement park. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the wrists as well as the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Range of motion of the wrists is limited. A lacy macular rash is noted over the trunk and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and antinuclear antibody and anti-dsDNA serology, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease, is a common childhood disease that can also affect adults. The disease typically manifests with mild febrile illness, occasionally followed by a maculopapular rash beginning on the perioral areas of the face several days later and spreading to the extremities from there. As the rash clears, it adopts a lacy and reticular pattern. Parvovirus B19 infection in adults may also manifest with symptoms of symmetric polyarthritis in the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles while the rash can be absent. The disease is usually self-limited and treatment is supportive, involving analgesics and NSAIDs.

B) INCORRECT:

Common findings in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include fever and joint pain as seen in this young female patient. However, dermatologic findings of SLE often include a malar rash, photosensitivity, or discoid lupus rather than a self-limited reticular rash on the extremities. In addition, this patient also has normal hemoglobin, normal ESR, negative antinuclear antibodies, negative anti-dsDNA, and normal renal function, which would be unlikely in SLE.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis manifests with the classic triad of acute onset of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis in roughly a third of cases. Although reactive arthritis can also be associated with fever and a runny nose, joint involvement usually includes asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis in the lower extremities, sacroiliitis, or enthesopathy. Furthermore, the patient does not have conjunctivitis, uveitis, oral lesions, diarrhea, or any urogenital tract symptoms that also present with reactive arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Around 2% of patients with Neisseria gonorrhoeae develop disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI). Although DGI may manifest with fever and polyarthralgias in the hands, this patient is missing other common symptoms such as dermatitis and tenosynovitis. Furthermore, arthritis caused by DGI is migratory and asymmetric, while this patient has symmetric polyarthritis in her hands and wrists.
Image Description:

A pustule with surrounding erythema is located on the left palm in the area of the 5th metacarpal bone.

E) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis can manifest with or without skin or nail findings and can also cause either symmetrical polyarthritis as in this patient or asymmetrical oligoarticular arthritis. However, the condition commonly involves the spine, the sacroiliac joint, and the distal interphalangeal joints, none of which are affected in this patient. Furthermore, psoriatic arthritis does not cause a reticular rash on the extremities, and lab values typically show an elevated ESR as psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient had symptoms that could be attributable to rheumatoid arthritis (RA), such as fever and symmetric polyarthralgia in the hands and wrists, this diagnosis is less likely because of her rash, normal ESR, and acute onset. If her arthritis symptoms do not resolve within a few weeks, however, she should undergo more specific testing for RA.
questions.hint: This young woman with a recent history of flu-like symptoms, a nonpruritic generalized rash, and acute bilateral upper extremity arthralgias likely contracted a self-limited disease given her exposure to young children.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-day history of mildly pruritic rash on her trunk and extremities. One week ago, she developed a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and headache, followed by a facial rash 4 days later. The facial rash did not involve the perioral skin. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash on her lower arms is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) is a viral exanthematous illness usually seen in unvaccinated children. As in this patient, this condition also causes cold-like symptoms and a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads distally. The rash, however, is usually nonconfluent and involves the perioral region.

B) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) is a paramyxovirus infection and manifests with a prodromal stage followed by an exanthem stage that is characterized by an erythematous confluent maculopapular rash. As in this patient, the rash starts on the face and extends to the body and is self-limiting. However, the rash of measles does not spare the perioral area and is usually accompanied by a high fever.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of prodromal low-grade fever and cold‑like symptoms, followed by a facial rash with perioral sparing (“slapped-cheek” appearance) that spreads to the trunk and extremities with a lace-like, reticular pattern, is consistent with erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Fifth disease is caused by a parvovirus B19 infection.

This condition is most commonly seen in children aged 5–15 years and is self-limiting, usually resolving in 7–10 days.

D) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a viral illness that is characterized by a pruritic maculopapular and vesicular rash primarily on the hands and feet. Although the rash can manifest with vesicles in the oropharynx, it does not involve the face. Additionally, the cold-like symptoms usually accompany the rash rather than precede it.
Image Description:

Hands and feet of a 36-year-old male patient

Macular and papular lesions are visible on the inner surface of the hands and feet.

The localization in conjunction with the enanthem of the mucous membranes is typical of hand, foot, and mouth disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Roseola (exanthem subitum) is an exanthematous illness caused by the human herpesvirus 6. This condition typically manifests in infants or toddlers with a high fever for 3–7 days that is immediately followed by a patchy maculopapular rash. Opposite of this patient's presentation, the rash seen in exanthem subitum starts on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities.

F) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever most commonly occurs in children with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and causes a fine, maculopapular rash with a sandpaper‑like texture. The face can be flushed with perioral pallor, which resembles the perioral-sparing rash described in this patient. However, the rash usually starts on the neck, axilla, and groin, and then spreads to the rest of the body.
questions.hint: Complications of this condition include hydrops fetalis in case of intrauterine transmission during pregnancy and aplastic crises in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists and a nonpruritic generalized rash. The stiffness is worst in the morning and improves after 15–20 minutes of activity. She had fever and a runny nose 10 days ago that resolved without treatment. She is sexually active with a male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. She works as an elementary school teacher. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling, tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the wrists as well as the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. There is a lacy macular rash over the trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and anti-nuclear antibody and anti-dsDNA serology, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Common findings in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include fever and joint pain as seen in this young female patient. However, dermatologic findings of lupus often include a malar rash, photosensitivity, or discoid lupus rather than a self-limited reticular rash on the extremities. In addition, this patient also has normal hemoglobin, normal ESR, negative anti-nuclear antibodies, negative anti-dsDNA, and normal renal function, which would be unlikely in SLE.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis can present with or without skin or nail findings and can also cause either a symmetrical polyarthritis as in this patient or an asymmetrical oligoarticular arthritis. However, the condition commonly involves the spine, the sacroiliac joint, and the distal interphalangeal joints, none of which are affected in this patient. Furthermore, psoriatic arthritis does not cause a reticular rash on the extremities, and lab values typically show an elevated ESR as psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory condition.

C) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease, is a common childhood disease that can also affect adults. The disease typically manifests with mild febrile illness, occasionally followed by a maculopapular rash beginning on the perioral areas of the face several days later and spreading to the extremities from there. As the rash clears, it adopts a lacy and reticular pattern, as seen in this patient. More commonly in adults, parvovirus B19 infection may also present with symptoms of symmetric polyarthritis in the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles while the rash can be absent. The disease is usually self-limited and treatment is supportive, involving analgesics and NSAIDs.

D) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis presents with the classic triad of acute onset of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis in roughly a third of cases. Although reactive arthritis can also be associated with fever and a runny nose, joint involvement usually includes asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis in the lower extremities, sacroiliitis, or enthesopathy. Furthermore, the patient does not have conjunctivitis, uveitis, oral lesions, diarrhea, or any urogenital tract symptoms that also present with reactive arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Around 2% of cases of Neisseria gonorrhoeae develop disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI). Although DGI may manifest with fever and polyarthralgia in the hands, this patient is missing other common symptoms such as dermatitis and tenosynovitis. Furthermore, arthritis caused by DGI is a migratory asymmetric arthritis, while this patient has symmetric polyarthritis in her hands and wrists.
Image Description:

A pustule with surrounding erythema is located on the left palm in the area of the 5th metacarpal bone.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient had symptoms that could be attributable to rheumatoid arthritis, such as fever and symmetric polyarthralgia in the hands and wrists, this diagnosis is less likely because of her rash, normal ESR, and acute onset. Furthermore, rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with morning stiffness that lasts for more than 30 minutes. If her arthritis symptoms do not resolve within a few weeks, however, she should undergo more specific testing for rheumatoid arthritis.
questions.hint: This young woman with a recent history of flu-like symptoms, a nonpruritic generalized rash, and acute bilateral upper extremity arthralgias likely contracted a self-limited disease given her exposure to young children.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a 1-day history of a pruritic rash on his trunk and face. Five days ago, he developed low-grade fever, nausea, and diarrhea. Physical examination shows a lace-like erythematous rash on the trunk and face with circumoral pallor. The agent most likely causing symptoms in this patient has selective tropism for which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., group A β‑hemolytic streptococci) display tropism for epithelial cells. Infection with GAS can cause scarlet fever, which manifests with an erythematous rash, perioral pallor, and fever, which are seen in this patient, but it would typically also cause pharyngitis and a white or strawberry tongue.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., EBV) display tropism for B lymphocytes. Infection with EBV can cause infectious mononucleosis, a highly contagious condition, which spreads via saliva (hence the name “kissing disease”). EBV infection can manifest with fever and pruritic rash, which are seen in this patient, but acute pharyngitis, tonsillitis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., VZV and HIV) display tropism for T lymphocytes. Given this patient's age, he could have chickenpox caused by a primary infection with VZV. Chickenpox typically manifests with a pruritic rash and fever, which are seen here. However, the rash would be more widespread, involving not only the face and trunk, but also the scalp, extremities, oral and urogenital mucosa, palms, and soles. Moreover, a characteristic feature of chickenpox is the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash (macules, papules, vesicles, crusted papules), which is not seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

A 7-year-old patient with a pruritic, lace-like erythematous rash on his trunk and face that developed 5 days after a low-grade fever, nausea, and diarrhea most likely has a parvovirus B19 infection. Parvovirus B19 has selective tropism for erythroid progenitor cells. Infection of these cells can result in temporary suspension of erythropoiesis, which leads to transient aplastic crisis.

E) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., VZV, HSV-1, or HSV-2) display tropism for sensory neuronal cells and remain dormant within sensory nerve ganglia following primary infection. A primary infection with VZV typically manifests with a pruritic rash and fever, which are seen in this patient. However, the rash would be more widespread, involving not only the face and trunk, but also the scalp, extremities, oral and urogenital mucosa, palms, and soles. Herpes simplex virus infections typically only cause localized symptoms (aphthous stomatitis, herpes labialis, or herpes genitalis).

F) INCORRECT:

Certain pathogens (e.g., the measles virus and CMV) display tropism for monocytes. While measles typically manifests with conjunctivitis, coryza, and cough, followed by sudden development of a high fever, malaise, and an erythematous, maculopapular rash, this patient presents with low-grade fever and a lace-like erythematous rash with perioral sparing. CMV infection usually remains asymptomatic in immunocompetent patients.
questions.hint: Infection with this pathogen during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 5-day history of a generalized rash. The rash started on the cheeks and has since spread to the rest of the body. His mother states that the rash is more prominent after he plays in their garden. Last week, he had a fever for 3 days and was treated with over-the-counter acetaminophen. The rash appeared after the fever resolved. His mother is concerned that he is allergic to acetaminophen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/63 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows erythema of the cheeks with perioral sparing. There is a diffuse, erythematous, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8000/mm3, and platelet count is 270,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Throat swab and empiric oral penicillin V therapy
Echocardiography, intravenous immunoglobulin, and aspirin therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A throat swab and empiric oral penicillin V therapy are appropriate management steps for scarlet fever, which can manifest with a rash that appears after the onset of fever. However, the rash seen in scarlet fever typically has a sandpaper texture, begins on the neck (not the cheeks) before spreading, and spares the palms and soles. Scarlet fever also causes pharyngitis and cervical lymphadenopathy, which this patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

A short course of oral prednisone is used to treat parvovirus B19-associated arthritis. Although this child has a parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum), there is no evidence of associated arthritis, which typically manifests as arthralgia with symmetric, nondestructive polyarthritis in the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles. Parvovirus B19-associated arthritis is uncommon in children, occurring in < 10% of cases.

C) INCORRECT:

In immunocompetent patients, serology for pathogen-specific antibody titers (e.g., IgG or IgM antibodies against parvovirus B19) is performed if the diagnosis is unclear (nonclassic presentation) or definitive etiologic diagnosis is necessary to determine the next steps in management. However, this patient presents with classic clinical features of erythema infectiosum, management recommendations for which are not affected by serologic confirmation.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography, intravenous immunoglobulin, and aspirin therapy are appropriate management steps for Kawasaki disease, which typically manifests with fever and a rash. However, the fever associated with Kawasaki disease typically persists for > 5 days, and the rash usually starts on the trunk, not the face. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of Kawasaki disease, such as conjunctivitis, stomatitis with chapped lips and a strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are sufficient, as erythema infectiosum is typically a self-limited condition in immunocompetent children. In < 10% of children, parvovirus B19-associated arthritis can occur, which typically manifests in the joints of the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles and resolves after 3–4 weeks. Analgesics and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents can be used supportively.

Though parvovirus B19 infection in children is usually self-limited, infection in pregnancy can cause severe anemia, fetal hydrops, and fetal demise.
questions.hint: This patient's flu-like illness and subsequent slapped-cheek rash on the face that consequently spread to the body is consistent with a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department reporting a 3-week history of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath with exertion. She was diagnosed with HIV infection 4 years ago when she was pregnant. She took antiretroviral therapy during her pregnancy but stopped immediately after the birth of her son. She has received no medical care since then. Her son is healthy and attends day care. The patient was born in Mexico City but has been in the United States for more than 20 years with no recent travel.
On examination, she is afebrile and has orthostatic hypotension. When she is supine, her blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 90 beats per minute. When she stands, her blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 120 beats per minute. She is thin and has oral thrush and marked conjunctival pallor. A systolic flow murmur is heard on auscultation of the heart.
She has a CD4 count of 100 cells/mm3 (reference range, 400–1600) and an HIV-1 viral load of 150,000 copies/mL.
Other laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
6.0
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
220,000
150,000–300,000


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4500
4500–11,000


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
0
0.5–2.5


Examination of bone-marrow aspirate reveals giant pronormoblasts.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Bone-marrow suppression due to advanced HIV infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus, disseminated Mycobacterium avium, histoplasmosis, and advanced HIV infection can all result in bone-marrow infiltration, suppression, or both, but these infections typically affect all cell lines simultaneously.

B) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus, disseminated Mycobacterium avium, histoplasmosis, and advanced HIV infection can all result in bone-marrow infiltration, suppression, or both, but these infections typically affect all cell lines simultaneously.

C) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus, disseminated Mycobacterium avium, histoplasmosis, and advanced HIV infection can all result in bone-marrow infiltration, suppression, or both, but these infections typically affect all cell lines simultaneously. In infiltrative bone-marrow processes, such as disseminated M. avium infection and histoplasmosis, the peripheral-blood smear may show changes typical of myelophthisis, such as nucleated erythrocytes, teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, and immature myeloid cells.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with immune deficiency states, such as advanced HIV infection, the absence of reticulocytes in the blood and the presence of giant pronormoblasts in the bone marrow is characteristic of a transient aplastic crisis from parvovirus B19 infection. Because immunodeficient patients are unable to form neutralizing antibodies against the virus and because parvovirus B19 has a predilection for erythroid progenitor cells, these patients may develop a persistent severe anemia due to pure red-cell aplasia.

Treatment for pure red-cell aplasia due to parvovirus B19 infection in people with HIV includes transfusion of blood products, antiretroviral therapy, and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Parvovirus B19 infection occurs worldwide; most people are seropositive by late adulthood. The most common clinical presentation is fifth disease (erythema infectiosum), which is a childhood exanthem characterized by the classic “slapped cheek” rash.

Key learning point: The most likely infectious cause of pure red-cell aplasia in a patient with advanced HIV infection is parvovirus B19.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus, disseminated Mycobacterium avium, histoplasmosis, and advanced HIV infection can all result in bone-marrow infiltration, suppression, or both, but these infections typically affect all cell lines simultaneously. In infiltrative bone-marrow processes, such as disseminated M. avium infection and histoplasmosis, the peripheral-blood smear may show changes typical of myelophthisis, such as nucleated erythrocytes, teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, and immature myeloid cells.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with painful, acutely swollen fingers and knees. She says that 5 days ago she felt like she had the flu. Her symptoms at that time were a mild headache, muscle aches, and a low-grade fever. She is up to date with all vaccinations, including Covid-19, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Her temperature is 37.3°C, and all vital signs are within normal limits. She has tenderness, erythema, and swelling of her metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally. Moderate effusions are evident in both knees, with tenderness to palpation and some limited range of motion. A faint maculopapular rash is evident on her arms and chest.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to reveal a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Immunoglobulin M testing for parvovirus B19

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disseminated gonococcal infection may manifest with tenosynovitis and dermatitis, and patients may have polyarthralgias. When disseminated gonococcal infection causes arthritis, it is often asymmetric.

B) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection is more likely than rheumatoid arthritis or other connective tissue disease if the presentation is acute and the patient has had a recent flulike illness.

C) INCORRECT:

Rubella infection is very rare in vaccinated adults and is often asymptomatic.

D) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection is more likely than rheumatoid arthritis or other connective tissue disease if the presentation is acute and the patient has had a recent flulike illness.

E) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 infection, common in both adults and children, is transmitted by the respiratory route. Serious infection is associated with immunosuppressed states or in utero infection, but most pediatric and adult cases are mild and self-limited in nature. The classic erythema infectiosum (or slapped-cheek appearance) in children usually does not occur in adults.

Arthralgias and arthritis are the most common manifestations of primary parvovirus B19 infection in immunocompetent adults, occurring in 60% of infected women and 30% of infected men. The small joints of the hands are most often affected, but the knees, wrists, and ankles are also commonly involved. Flulike symptoms such as fever, headache, and malaise, as well as a maculopapular rash, can also be present in otherwise healthy infected adults. Outbreaks are often associated with work in daycare or school settings.

The arthritis is nonerosive and is thought to be immune-mediated, given that the timing is coincident with the presence of immunoglobulin M in the serum. The diagnosis of parvovirus B19 infection in healthy adults is confirmed by detecting antiparvovirus immunoglobulin M antibodies in serum.

Key learning point: In an otherwise healthy adult, acute symmetric polyarthritis associated with a recent flulike illness is a common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection.

questions.text:
A healthy 11-month-old girl is brought in for evaluation of a new rash that began the day before. The mother reports that the girl had a fever, cough, and malaise for the past 3 to 4 days. The fevers have decreased with acetaminophen treatment, and the patient is improving clinically, but the mother is concerned about the rash. The girl has not been exposed to any new medications or foods.
Her vital signs are normal, and she appears well. She has erythematous macules on her cheeks and a lace-like rash on her trunk and upper extremities (figure). She has no conjunctival injection or lymphadenopathy. The rest of her examination is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a common childhood illness caused by coxsackie virus. It is characterized by painful blisters in the back of the mouth (herpangina) and an erythematous rash, often accompanied by blisters, affecting the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.

B) INCORRECT:

Roseola is a childhood viral exanthem caused by human herpesvirus 6 and 7. It is usually characterized by the acute development of a high fever followed by the appearance of a morbilliform rash during defervescence. It can also be associated with febrile seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Drug sensitivity reactions appear as erythematous macules any time during or immediately after exposure to the drug and typically manifest as a morbilliform eruption or urticaria.

D) CORRECT:

This child has erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, a common childhood viral exanthem that is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

The illness begins with prodromal symptoms of fever, cough, malaise, and diarrhea, which coincide with the onset of viremia. These constitutional symptoms typically precede the classic erythematous, malar rash that makes the cheeks look as if they have been slapped. A lace-like, reticular rash often affects the trunk and extremities. The incubation period from exposure to onset of the rash ranges from 1 to 3 weeks. The rash typically resolves within a few weeks but can resolve and recur over months with environmental changes such as temperature. Approximately 10% of children infected with parvovirus B19 will have associated arthritis.

Key learning point: Fever, cough, malaise, a "slapped cheek" rash, and a lacy rash on the extremities is most characteristic of the diagnosis of erythema infectiosum.

E) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) and is characterized by fever, exudative pharyngitis, and an exanthem that is often described as feeling rough, like sandpaper.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old primigravida woman at 16 weeks’ gestation says that she was exposed to a child with parvovirus B19 infection within the past 48 hours while she was working at a day-care center. She feels well and has no signs or symptoms of infection.
Laboratory testing reveals negative results for both parvovirus B19 immunoglobulin M and immunoglobulin G.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reassure the patient that she is not at risk for fetal complications
Repeat testing in 2 weeks — or earlier if symptoms occur
Arrange for a targeted fetal ultrasound

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given the risks associated with parvovirus B19 exposure during pregnancy, reassurance would not be appropriate without further testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal electrocardiography is not indicated in the workup of parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy.

C) CORRECT:

Pregnant women are at increased risk for infection if they are exposed to infected children in their own household. Working as school teacher or day-care worker may also put them at increased risk.

Parvovirus B19 infection in pregnant women does not typically harm the fetus. However, it can occasionally cause severe fetal anemia, cardiac failure, possibly hydrops fetalis, and even death. The highest risk for fetal infection is between 9 and 20 weeks’ gestation and within 2 to 4 weeks after maternal infection.

This patient has tested negative for both parvovirus B19 immunoglobulin G (IgG) and immunoglobulin M (IgM), which means she is susceptible to the virus. Repeat serologic testing in 2 to 4 weeks is warranted. If the patient tests positive for parvovirus B19 IgM on the repeat test, she should undergo serial ultrasounds to evaluate for evidence of hydrops fetalis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a woman who was exposed to parvovirus B19 at 16 weeks' gestation and who has no immunity is repeat testing for parvovirus B19 immunoglobulin M and immunoglobulin G in 2 to 4 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

A targeted fetal ultrasound is not helpful in the absence of confirmed infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is sometimes used for adults who have anemia from chronic parvovirus B19 infection, but it is not indicated in a pregnant woman who has been exposed to parvovirus B19.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because of a 5-day history of a generalized rash. The rash started on the cheeks and has since spread to the rest of the body. His mother states that the rash is more prominent after he plays in their garden. Last week, he had a fever for 3 days and was treated with over-the-counter acetaminophen. The rash appeared after the fever resolved. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/63 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows erythema of the cheeks with perioral sparing. There is a diffuse, erythematous, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Throat swab and empiric oral penicillin V therapy
Echocardiography, intravenous immunoglobulin, and aspirin therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A throat swab and empiric oral penicillin V therapy are appropriate management steps for scarlet fever, which can manifest with a rash that appears after the onset of fever. However, the rash seen in scarlet fever typically has a sandpaper texture, begins on the neck (not the cheeks) before spreading, and spares the palms and soles. Scarlet fever also causes pharyngitis and cervical lymphadenopathy, which this patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

A short course of oral prednisone is used to treat parvovirus B19-associated arthritis. Although this child has a parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum), there is no evidence of associated arthritis, which typically manifests as arthralgia with symmetric, nondestructive polyarthritis in the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles. Parvovirus B19-associated arthritis is uncommon in children, occurring in < 10% of cases.

C) INCORRECT:

In immunocompetent patients, serology for pathogen-specific antibody titers (e.g., IgG or IgM antibodies against parvovirus B19) is performed if the diagnosis is unclear (nonclassic presentation) or definitive etiologic diagnosis is necessary to determine the next steps in management. However, this patient presents with classic clinical features of erythema infectiosum, management recommendations for which are not affected by serologic confirmation.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography, intravenous immunoglobulin, and aspirin therapy are appropriate management steps for Kawasaki disease, which typically manifests with fever and a rash. However, the fever associated with Kawasaki disease typically persists for > 5 days, and the rash usually starts on the trunk, not the face. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of Kawasaki disease, such as conjunctivitis, stomatitis with chapped lips and a strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are sufficient, as erythema infectiosum is typically a self-limited condition in immunocompetent children. In < 10% of children, parvovirus B19-associated arthritis can occur, which typically manifests in the joints of the fingers, hands, knees, and ankles and resolves after 3–4 weeks. Analgesics and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents can be used supportively.

Though parvovirus B19 infection in children is usually self-limited, infection in pregnancy can cause severe anemia, fetal hydrops, and fetal demise.
questions.hint: This patient's flu-like illness and subsequent slapped-cheek rash on the face that consequently spread to the body is consistent with a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because of a 2-day history of reticular rash on her trunk and extremities. One week ago, she developed a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and headache, followed by a facial rash resembling flushed cheeks. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash on her lower arms is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) is a viral exanthematous illness usually seen in unvaccinated children. As in this patient, this condition also causes cold-like symptoms and a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads distally. The rash, however, is usually nonconfluent and involves the perioral region.

B) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) is a paramyxovirus infection and manifests with a prodromal stage followed by an exanthem stage that is characterized by an erythematous confluent maculopapular rash. As in this patient, the rash starts on the face and extends to the body and is self-limiting. However, the rash of measles does not spare the perioral area and is usually accompanied by a high fever.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of prodromal low-grade fever and cold‑like symptoms, followed by a facial rash with perioral sparing (“slapped-cheek” appearance) that spreads to the trunk and extremities with a lace-like, reticular pattern, is consistent with erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Fifth disease is caused by a parvovirus B19 infection.

This condition is most commonly seen in children aged 5–15 years and is self-limiting, usually resolving in 7–10 days.

D) INCORRECT:

Roseola (exanthem subitum) is an exanthematous illness caused by the human herpesvirus 6. This condition typically manifests in infants or toddlers with a high fever for 3–7 days that is immediately followed by a patchy maculopapular rash. Opposite of this patient's presentation, the rash seen in exanthem subitum starts on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities.

E) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever most commonly occurs in children with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and causes a fine, maculopapular rash with a sandpaper‑like texture. The face can be flushed with perioral pallor, which resembles the perioral-sparing rash described in this patient. However, the rash usually starts on the neck, axilla, and groin, and then spreads to the rest of the body.
questions.hint: Complications of this condition include hydrops fetalis in case of intrauterine transmission during pregnancy and aplastic crises in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A healthy 11-month-old girl is brought in for evaluation of a new rash that began the day before. The mother reports that the girl had a fever, cough, and malaise for the past 3 to 4 days. The fevers have decreased with acetaminophen treatment, and the patient is improving clinically, but the mother is concerned about the rash. The girl has not been exposed to any new medications or foods. Her vital signs are normal, and she appears well. She has erythematous macules on her cheeks and a lace-like rash on her trunk and upper extremities. She has no conjunctival injection or lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the rash is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a common childhood illness caused by coxsackie virus. It is characterized by painful blisters in the back of the mouth (herpangina) and an erythematous rash, often accompanied by blisters, affecting the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.

B) INCORRECT:

Roseola is a childhood viral exanthem caused by human herpesvirus 6 and 7. It is usually characterized by the acute development of a high fever followed by the appearance of a morbilliform rash during defervescence. It can also be associated with febrile seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Drug sensitivity reactions appear as erythematous macules any time during or immediately after exposure to the drug and typically manifest as a morbilliform eruption or urticaria.

D) CORRECT:

This child has erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, a common childhood viral exanthem that is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

The illness begins with prodromal symptoms of fever, cough, malaise, and diarrhea, which coincide with the onset of viremia. These constitutional symptoms typically precede the classic erythematous, malar rash that makes the cheeks look as if they have been slapped. A lace-like, reticular rash often affects the trunk and extremities. The incubation period from exposure to onset of the rash ranges from 1 to 3 weeks. The rash typically resolves within a few weeks but can resolve and recur over months with environmental changes such as temperature. Approximately 10% of children infected with parvovirus B19 will have associated arthritis.

Key learning point: Fever, cough, malaise, a "slapped cheek" rash, and a lacy rash on the extremities is most characteristic of the diagnosis of erythema infectiosum.

E) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) and is characterized by fever, exudative pharyngitis, and an exanthem that is often described as feeling rough, like sandpaper.

questions.text: At 22 weeks’ gestation, a pregnant woman presents with fever, arthralgias, and a facial rash. Serology confirms parvovirus B19 infection. What fetal complication is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 has a strong affinity for erythroid precursor cells, leading to fetal anemia when the virus crosses the placenta. This anemia results in increased cardiac output to maintain oxygen delivery, causing high-output cardiac failure. The cardiac strain leads to nonimmune hydrops fetalis, characterized by fluid accumulation in fetal compartments such as the pleural, pericardial, and peritoneal spaces, and subcutaneous edema. The pathophysiology involves disruption of fetal erythropoiesis by viral cytopathy, triggering anemia-induced cardiac failure and subsequent hydrops.

Key learning point: Maternal infection with Parvovirus B19 can lead to fetal complications such as severe anemia, fetal hydrops, and potentially fetal death.

B) INCORRECT:

Intracranial calcifications are linked to congenital infections like cytomegalovirus or toxoplasmosis, which affect the central nervous system. Parvovirus B19 targets erythroid precursors, causing fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis, not brain calcifications.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect is a structural heart defect from embryologic development errors. Parvovirus B19 targets erythroid progenitor cells, leading to fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis, not structural cardiac malformations.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital cataracts are associated with intrauterine infections like rubella, where viral invasion affects lens development. Parvovirus B19 targets erythroid precursor cells, causing fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis, not ocular abnormalities.

questions.text: You are seeing an 11-year-old girl brought to your clinic by her parents because of a 2-day history of a reticular rash on her trunk and extremities. One week ago, she developed a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and headache, which was followed by a facial rash resembling flushed cheeks. Her temperature is 37.4°C, pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash on her lower arms is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) is a viral exanthematous illness usually seen in unvaccinated children. As in this patient, this condition also causes cold-like symptoms and a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads distally. The rash, however, is usually nonconfluent and involves the perioral region.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of prodromal low-grade fever and cold‑like symptoms, followed by a facial rash with perioral sparing (“slapped-cheek” appearance) that spreads to the trunk and extremities with a lace-like, reticular pattern, is consistent with erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Fifth disease is caused by a parvovirus B19 infection.

This condition is most commonly seen in children aged 5–15 years and is self-limiting, usually resolving in 7–10 days.

Key learning point: Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is a self-limited childhood illness caused by parvovirus B19, presenting with a "slapped-cheek" facial rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and extremities.

C) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) is a paramyxovirus infection and manifests with a prodromal stage followed by an exanthem stage that is characterized by an erythematous confluent maculopapular rash. As in this patient, the rash starts on the face and extends to the body and is self-limiting. However, the rash of measles does not spare the perioral area and is usually accompanied by a high fever.

D) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever most commonly occurs in children with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and causes a fine, maculopapular rash with a sandpaper‑like texture. The face can be flushed with perioral pallor, which resembles the perioral-sparing rash described in this patient. However, the rash usually starts on the neck, axilla, and groin, and then spreads to the rest of the body.

E) INCORRECT:

Roseola (exanthem subitum) is an exanthematous illness caused by the human herpesvirus 6. This condition typically manifests in infants or toddlers with a high fever for 3 days that is immediately followed by a patchy maculopapular rash. Opposite of this patient's presentation, the rash seen in exanthem subitum starts on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities.
questions.hint: Complications of this condition include hydrops fetalis in case of intrauterine transmission during pregnancy and aplastic crises in patients with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: You are seeing an 11-month-old girl brought to your clinic for evaluation of a new rash that started yesterday. Her mother reports that she had fever, cough, and malaise for the past 3 to 4 days. The fever has improved with acetaminophen, and the child is clinically improving, but her mother is concerned about the rash. There have been no new medications or foods. Vital signs are normal. She has erythematous macules on her cheeks and a lace-like rash on her trunk and upper extremities. There is no conjunctival injection or lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the rash is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Roseola is a childhood viral exanthem caused by human herpesvirus 6 and 7. It is usually characterized by the acute development of a high fever followed by the appearance of a morbilliform rash during defervescence. It can also be associated with febrile seizures.

B) INCORRECT:

Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) and is characterized by fever, exudative pharyngitis, and an exanthem that is often described as feeling rough, like sandpaper.

C) INCORRECT:

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a common childhood illness caused by coxsackie virus. It is characterized by painful blisters in the back of the mouth (herpangina) and an erythematous rash, often accompanied by blisters, affecting the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug sensitivity reactions appear as erythematous macules any time during or immediately after exposure to the drug and typically manifest as a morbilliform eruption or urticaria.

E) CORRECT:

This child has erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, a common childhood viral exanthem that is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

The illness begins with prodromal symptoms of fever, cough, malaise, and diarrhea, which coincide with the onset of viremia. These constitutional symptoms typically precede the classic erythematous, malar rash that makes the cheeks look as if they have been slapped. A lace-like, reticular rash often affects the trunk and extremities. The incubation period from exposure to onset of the rash ranges from 1 to 3 weeks. The rash typically resolves within a few weeks but can resolve and recur over months with environmental changes such as temperature. Approximately 10% of children infected with parvovirus B19 will have associated arthritis.

Key learning point: Fever, cough, malaise, a "slapped cheek" rash, and a lacy rash on the extremities is most characteristic of the diagnosis of erythema infectiosum.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother who is concerned about a rash that developed yesterday. The child had a runny nose and low-grade fever one week ago that resolved without treatment. He appears well and is afebrile. Physical examination shows bilateral facial erythema with clear skin around the mouth and a lace-like rash on his arms and trunk. His 3-year-old sister at home has sickle cell disease. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Counsel regarding risk to household contacts
Obtain throat culture and prescribe antibiotics
Advise school exclusion until rash resolves

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular penicillin is not indicated for viral infections. Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19 and does not respond to antibiotic therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- A household contact with sickle cell disease requires immediate counseling about risk of infection. Children with chronic hemolytic diseases such as sickle cell disease are at risk for transient aplastic crisis when exposed to parvovirus B19. The family should be educated about monitoring the sister for signs of severe anemia and to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms develop. By the time the rash develops, immunocompetent children with parvovirus B19 are no longer infectious, so the child can return to school.

C) INCORRECT:

While antihistamines may help treat pruritus, if present, the most appropriate next step is addressing the risk to the household contact with sickle cell disease. The sister is at significant risk for aplastic crisis and requires monitoring and precautions.

D) INCORRECT:

Throat culture and antibiotics are not indicated for erythema infectiosum, which is a viral infection caused by parvovirus B19. The characteristic facial rash with perioral sparing and reticular trunk pattern are diagnostic of fifth disease.

E) INCORRECT:

School exclusion is not necessary for children with erythema infectiosum once the characteristic rash appears. Erythema infectiosum is only contagious during the prodromal phase before the rash develops.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of bilateral wrist and finger joint pain that developed acutely. She reports morning stiffness lasting 30 minutes and mild fatigue. Physical examination shows symmetric swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints and wrists with limited range of motion. Vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies show normal complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. The patient's child, who attends daycare, is with her and appears flushed (shown in the photograph). What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Synovial fluid analysis is indicated if septic arthritis or crystal arthropathy is suspected. This patient's bilateral symmetric presentation with daycare exposure and normal vital signs makes parvovirus B19-associated arthritis more likely than septic arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

While rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis, the acute onset, daycare exposure, and normal inflammatory markers favor parvovirus B19-associated arthritis, which requires supportive management rather than extensive rheumatologic workup.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Parvovirus B19-associated arthritis in adults manifests with acute-onset symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints, particularly hands and wrists. The daycare exposure and acute presentation with normal inflammatory markers support this diagnosis. Treatment is supportive with NSAIDs for symptom relief, and patients should be reassured that the condition is self-limited, usually within 2 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic corticosteroids are not indicated for parvovirus B19-associated arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is used for rheumatoid arthritis and other chronic inflammatory arthritides. Parvovirus B19-associated arthritis is self-limited and nondestructive, typically resolving within 2 weeks without disease-modifying therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of acute-onset bilateral joint pain and swelling of her hands, wrists, and ankles. She reports mild fatigue but denies fever or rash. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. Physical examination shows symmetric swelling and tenderness of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Vital signs are normal. She has a 3-year-old son who attends daycare and recently had a mild febrile illness. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe NSAIDs and arrange primary care follow-up
Refer to rheumatology for urgent evaluation
Obtain parvovirus B19 IgM and IgG antibodies
Order rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Given the missed menstrual period and clinical presentation consistent with parvovirus B19-associated arthritis, pregnancy status must be determined first. Parvovirus B19 is a TORCH infection that requires obstetric referral and monitoring for fetal complications. All pregnant patients with suspected parvovirus B19 require specialist referral.

B) INCORRECT:

While NSAIDs are appropriate for symptomatic treatment of parvovirus B19-associated arthritis, pregnancy status must be determined first given the missed menstrual period. Parvovirus B19 is a TORCH infection that can cause fetal complications including hydrops fetalis and miscarriage.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate rheumatology referral is not necessary for typical parvovirus B19-associated arthritis in immunocompetent patients. Acute symmetrical polyarthritis usually resolves within 2 weeks with supportive care. The missed menstrual period makes establishing this patient's pregnancy status a priority.

D) INCORRECT:

Confirmatory parvovirus B19 testing is indicated for pregnant patients because of the risk of congenital infection. However, pregnancy status should be established first before proceeding with specific testing and obstetric referral.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor testing may be considered if symptoms persist beyond several weeks, but the acute onset and clinical presentation are more consistent with viral arthritis. Furthermore, pregnancy status takes priority in this patient with a missed menstrual period.
